body: OK I made the changes ScottNZ wanted. Another review pls.
OK I have again fixed some issues. Looks finished to me. Another review please.

It displays my owner timers in a redundant and glitchy way with cheats on:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/756669/7442292/ba70c266-f10b-11e4-95aa-4426e7f75862.png)
I fixed the issue with player turning shroud off in debug menu. It was caused by incomplete player state checks.

For reference, here are the player state conditions I used:
Condition --means--> we are ...
LocalPlayer is not null and winstate is undefined --> player in gameplay

If that is not true but

RenderPlayer is not null and RenderPlayer.InternalName is not "Everyone" --> Observer with a player view selected

If that is also not true --> Observer with "all players" or disable shroud view selected.

I also created a diagram showing player states:
![player_states](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6599106/7490202/078aa156-f3e7-11e4-9033-d183480a1e75.png)
Do you have source data for that visualization?

Here are the .odg and .svg files:
https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B_dMvsHPqPZkfjVmYkc2ODZnRFM4ZXVHUWpyOXJQQmxHcGhnQmJjb0ZvN2FFeXZSdGVyM0k&usp=sharing
Oh, my mistake. I thought this was actually representing statistics of some type.
Is there any special reason why you only added this to the ra mod?
Do other mods have SUPPORT_POWER_TIMER?
Looks like it's only ra and d2k.
Added d2k yaml definitions and squashed commits.
This patch doesn't affect d2k though. D2k apparently doesn't have support power timers.

Something is fishy here. Either D2k has them and you can change them if you want (this is a UI improvement, so it's not necessary to be in all mods), or doesn't have them, in which case there is no reason to change the YAML there.
It has the widget definition in yaml but doesn't use them in game?
Deleted SupportPowerTimer@SUPPORT_POWER_TIMER: field from d2k. Nothing broke in test game...

OK, the amount of enumeration done on _each tick_ is just ridiculous. Here are some suggestions:
1. Add a countdown it Tick() and only do the work every second, like most traits do.
2. The 25 `IEnumerable`s aren't necessary, but they do clutter the code a lot.
- Add a local `List<SupportPowerInstance>` in Tick() and set it to `allPowers.ToList()`, then use that instead of `allPowers` to avoid tons of pointless enumeration.
- Then get rid of all the very specific collections and have only two (groupOne and groupTwo). You do use only 2 at a time, max (or maybe 3?). Fill those in Tick(), filtering the new list and taking into account what should go into each accorting to `Order`. Maybe do the same for the texts, but I am not convinced the players need their own collections at all.
- That allows you to replace the 15 usages of `DrawTimers()` with just 2.

Also a few comments wouldn't hurt.

There are way too many enumerations and conditional branches going on.  You can drop all of those by:
- Keep a dictionary of Player, SupportPowerManager.  This will not change, and can be cached in the constructor.
- When rendering, use GroupBy to separate the list of players into allies and enemies and then:
  1. For each group, enumerate over each player and draw their name in the left hand column at the current row, then:
     
     a.  For each power in the SupportPowerManager for that player, draw the timer name and time.
     b.  Increment the current row
  2. Increment the current row.

OK, I have improved the code. Now there is a single collection of texts and the Draw() method draws each element in it. The actual logic and calculations are in Tick(). And they are executed once every 12 ticks which is about half a second. But Draw() is run at a much higher frequency, even higher than the tick frequency I think. So I wanted to minimize Draw() method and do as much as possible in Tick(). I didn't use GroupBy because I couldn't think of a way to fit that into the rest of the logic. I found it easier to do it with separate lists.

This code still has the problem of having custom widget bounds to move the timers to the left when in observer mode. How can I do it with UI yaml or other widget logic?

Also I could have done this without the custom struct definition, using a single array. The zero index of the array could contain left column and any higher indices would be right column. But I think this is more explanatory and easier to understand.
Using GroupBy lets you remove the last of your explicit state management (simplifying the code a lot more), and also the half-second update requirement.

The half second update is not related to the logic. I just did that to reduce the number of calculations and because I thought half second updating would be enough.

I can't find a way to use GroupBy which would reduce calculations or simplify the code. It would not be enough to group texts according to player stance, the headers would also need to be inserted to specific locations depending on the number of elements (no allied text -> don't add allies header). And the texts would be in an array or list so that they can be grouped. This wouldn't reduce the amount of allocation. At least this is how I understand it. Is the current code not simple enough? If not, can you show me how I could simplify it?

I noticed some diplomacy stance issues:
If playerA's stance to playerB is `Enemy` but playerB's stance to playerA is `Ally`,
playerA's timers are listed under `Allies` (even though he's actually an enemy).
And the other way round, same with the `Neutral`-stance, etc.

That's by design. The player decides who is his ally. So if player B sets player A as his ally, then that's his ally. Should it also require player A to reciprocate? And how should neutral players be treated? Should there be a third group called Neutral?
Moved SupportPowerTimer from Container@WORLD_ROOT: to Container@PLAYER_WIDGETS: and Container@OBSERVER_WIDGETS:

You're misunderstanding the issue. 

If A is an enemy of B, then B should show up as an enemy, not an ally.

If B is (at the same time) an ally of A, then A should show as an ally, not as an enemy.

At the moment, when A is an enemy of B but B is an ally of A, B shows up as an ally.

A third group for neutral should not be made IMO.
On 2015-05-24, at 9:30 PM, Deniz notifications@github.com wrote:

> That's by design. The player decides who is his ally. So if player B sets player A as his ally, then that's his ally. Should it also require player A to reciprocate? And how should neutral players be treated? Should there be a third group called Neutral?
> 
> ―
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
Hm ok, so the support power owner's stance should decide in which group the timers are shown? Not the viewing player's?
IMHO the owner's stance is more reasonable.
Agreed with @abcdefg30 you want to see what may be used against you.
